issue.title: Default value derived from function with optional output parameter broke first time migration

comment.body: Perhaps this is not a bug but expected behavior since default values can be used to seed properties. Then you need to describe a method for solving similar problems - for example, a flag that disables seeding during the first migration, etc.

issue.title: Default value derived from function with optional output parameter broke first time migration
using group by with coalescing operator in for don't return proper result
issue.body:
- EdgeDB Version:4.0-rc.1+fd5ed53
- 
Steps to Reproduce:
1.  let run following against example database

```
with movies := <json>$user,upserts:=(
  for item in json_array_unpack(movies) union( 
    (result:=(update Movie filter .id=<uuid>item["id"] set {title:=<str>item["title"]}),action:="update")??
    (result:=(insert Movie{title:=<str>item["title"]}),action:="insert")
  )
), select upserts;
```
```
*the first uuid has exists in database
[{"id":"37c0405c-748e-11ee-8f1a-63a529572c33","title":"Ant-Man"},{"id":"44b8a80c-730e-11ee-870f-5f740295ccc9","title":"new movie1"},{"id":"a62a35c8-730f-11ee-95b6-d3c0e5fa3823","title":"new movie2"}]
```

Yes, it will work correct
![image](https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb/assets/16233397/37caee40-05fc-49d2-aa68-0f6fc8391922)

one is updated and other two are inserted
2.Then change the `select upserts` to `group upserts by .action`
![image](https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb/assets/16233397/9ef8b5ac-455b-4425-9038-2a493811a6dd)
Then then elements of action:insert will be empty.
![image](https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb/assets/16233397/1fec5e8c-8b74-447e-84dd-c0d6b901dff5)

issue.title: Using splat in coalescing operator don't return all expected properties.
issue.body:
- EdgeDB Version:4.0-rc.1+fd5ed53

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Just run following edgedql against example movie database.
```
select (select Movie filter .title = "Ant-Man2")??(insert Movie{title:="Ant-Man2"}){*}
```
Then it will return only id property
![image](https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb/assets/16233397/f3ee4f84-4e68-4265-b741-fadbad2e0c90)

If I specify the properties 
```
select (select Movie filter .title = "Ant-Man2")??(insert Movie{title:="Ant-Man2"}){id,title}
```
The result would be the same.

And I will add more `*`
```
```
select (select Movie filter .title = "Ant-Man2")??(insert Movie{title:="Ant-Man2"}){**}
```
It will throw an error
![image](https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb/assets/16233397/07f7ba48-00fd-4276-95b6-6650d81ef518)

issue.title: Feature Request: Schema support for links inside collections

comment.body:
> Link properties are the intended solution to this problem.
> 
> We ought to support `required` on them, though you can mostly simulate that with an expression constraint that requires that it EXISTS.
> 
> File a bug against edgedb-ui if there's not a way to see the linkprops nicely?

I've got a couple issues for this already filed in the edgedb-ui repo.  See the following:
- https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb-ui/issues/51#issuecomment-1762697890
- https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb-ui/issues/275

Linkprops + general UI improvements are probably a suitable solution for my use-case as outlined above, however, I feel that the overall proposal to support arbitrary types (including links) within collections is still novel, and worth consideration on its own.

A core "feature" to this is the allowance of embedded data within an object, without the added overhead of an intermediary table bloating the schema.

commits.message: +to_str for bytes
+base64 en/decode functions

issue.title: contains() for json doesn't work when casting to <json>
issue.body:
(Context: contains() for json has been added to 4.0 and am writing documentation for it)

I think this is a bug, if not then will be a note to add to the documentation to explain the behaviour.

- EdgeDB Version: 4.0-beta.1+0f54951'
- EdgeDB CLI Version: 3.5.0+40f966d
- OS Version: Windows 11

Steps to Reproduce:

```
edgedb> with str1 := '{"Hi": "Bye", "One": "Two"}',
....... str2 := '{"Hi": "Bye"}',
....... select {
....... contains(to_json(str1), to_json(str2)),
....... contains(<json>str1, <json>str2)
....... };
{true, false}
```

I see the two jsons generated from the strings aren't quite equivalent to each other and a to_json(string) and a `<json>`string will display differently:

```
edgedb> with str1 := '{"Hi": "Bye", "One": "Two"}',
....... str2 := '{"Hi": "Bye"}',
....... select
....... { to_json(str1), <json>str1 };
{
  Json("{\"Hi\": \"Bye\", \"One\": \"Two\"}"),
  Json("\"{\\\"Hi\\\": \\\"Bye\\\", \\\"One\\\": \\\"Two\\\"}\""),
}
```

issue.title: contains() for json doesn't work when casting to <json>
issue.body:
(Context: contains() for json has been added to 4.0 and am writing documentation for it)

I think this is a bug, if not then will be a note to add to the documentation to explain the behaviour.

- EdgeDB Version: 4.0-beta.1+0f54951'
- EdgeDB CLI Version: 3.5.0+40f966d
- OS Version: Windows 11

Steps to Reproduce:

```
edgedb> with str1 := '{"Hi": "Bye", "One": "Two"}',
....... str2 := '{"Hi": "Bye"}',
....... select {
....... contains(to_json(str1), to_json(str2)),
....... contains(<json>str1, <json>str2)
....... };
{true, false}
```

I see the two jsons generated from the strings aren't quite equivalent to each other and a to_json(string) and a `<json>`string will display differently:

```
edgedb> with str1 := '{"Hi": "Bye", "One": "Two"}',
....... str2 := '{"Hi": "Bye"}',
....... select
....... { to_json(str1), <json>str1 };
{
  Json("{\"Hi\": \"Bye\", \"One\": \"Two\"}"),
  Json("\"{\\\"Hi\\\": \\\"Bye\\\", \\\"One\\\": \\\"Two\\\"}\""),
}
```

comment.body:
> I see the two jsons generated from the strings aren't quite equivalent to each other and a to_json(string) and a `<json>`string will display differently:
> 
> ```
> edgedb> with str1 := '{"Hi": "Bye", "One": "Two"}',
> ....... str2 := '{"Hi": "Bye"}',
> ....... select
> ....... { to_json(str1), <json>str1 };
> {
>   Json("{\"Hi\": \"Bye\", \"One\": \"Two\"}"),
>   Json("\"{\\\"Hi\\\": \\\"Bye\\\", \\\"One\\\": \\\"Two\\\"}\""),
> }
> ```

Yes, casting a string to json produces a json object that is a json-string.
It doesn't parse the string as json, which is what `to_json` does.

This all seems to be working as intended?

issue.title: Feature Request: Schema support for links inside collections

comment.body:
Link properties are the intended solution to this problem.

We ought to support `required` on them, though you can mostly simulate that with an expression constraint that requires that it EXISTS.

File a bug against edgedb-ui if there's not a way to see the linkprops nicely?

commits.message:
Preload the parser for docs tests (#6359)

Tested with
```
edb test tests/test_docs.py
```

Avoid pickling schemas on _every_ DDL statement when restoring a dump (#6362)

`restore()` doesn't care about anything other than compiled SQL or
config ops, so pickling and returning the schema with every DDL query
unit is wasteful, and, if the schema is large, quite slow.

Change adaptive pool scale-up condition (#6357)

Now scaling-up will be triggerd by a compile request waiting in the
queue for more than 3 seconds.

Fixes #4680

Move script entrypoints from `setup.py` to `pyproject.toml` (#6366)

The latest victim of the ongoing march of Python packaging deprecations
is the `entry_points` argument.  We stopped doing dynamic things to
entrypoints in `setup.py` some time ago anyway, so it's an easy fix.

docs: update Deno import to use the full URL (#6365)

See title - the Deno code snippet is slightly off

Do not log exception on invalid data (#6364)

The response should include enough information to be useful for
debugging, no need to also log to stdout.

Make ext::auth::ClientTokenIdentity single (#6369)

We don't have a great story currently for how to fix this kind of
extension issue, so for now let's resort to the tried-and-true method
and fixing it in the compiler :(.
Document HTTP authentication support (#6368)

Try running HA tets on postgres 14 again (#6370)

Until #6332 is fixed, at least.

Don't cache UI assets in memory when the Admin UI is disabled (#6367)

Saves ~10MiB or about 10% of all Python allocations in the baseline.

Fix some docs typos (#6331)

* Update connection.rst

EDGEDB_USER, EDGEDB_DATABASE and EDGEDB_PASSWORD are deprecated using EDGEDB_SERVER_USER, EDGEDB_SERVER_DATABASE and EDGEDB_SERVER_PASSWORD instead respectively.

* Update docker.rst

Fix typo

* Update index.rst

* Update schema.rst

Fix typo

* tweak

* Revert SERVER_ additions

---------

Co-authored-by: hitrust <cnhitrust@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Dhghomon <56599343+Dhghomon@users.noreply.github.com>
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/edgedb/edgedb into 4.0-additional-changes

issue.title: Update graphiql to forked version with globals support
issue.body:
Updates the `/graphql/explore` endpoint to serve a customised version of the GraphiQL UI built from this fork: https://github.com/edgedb/graphiql/tree/globals-editor with support for globals.

The bundled js/css files from this custom build are committed to this repo, so as not to add further complexity to the edgedb build (and they're unlikely to be updated frequently anyway). To re-build these files run the `edb/graphql/explore/build.sh` script.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2085287/231461019-bdc17782-2469-40ee-b21e-b37950869f58.png)

comment.body:
In 4.0, we allow passing in globals via variables using `__globals__`.
Does that obsolete this?

pull_request.title: [DRAFT] An fts::test that hits indexes
pull_request.body:
Implement an inlined version of fts::test that succefully hits
indexes. (I tested using imdbench extended with some fts::textsearch
indexes, and added some tests to the explain tests)

Per some discussions with @vpetrovykh, I introduced an fts::make_doc
function that is a variadic optional function that produces a string
that can be reasonable passed to an fts::textsearch index and that
works well will fts::test. (fts::test does the same operations.)

make_doc essentially does `array_to_string("docs", ' ')`, but inlined.

The most fiddly bit about all of this, though, in handling the
language argument to postgres's `to_tsvector`, and how it interacts
with our constant extraction preprocessing. Because we extract string
literals during preprocessing, the `language` argument to `fts::test`
and similar will typically be a parameter.

The language argument is of type `regconfig` (which is an int id);
there is a cast from `text` to `regconfig`, but if the argument to
language is a text query parameter cast to `regconfig`, the index will
not match and the query will be slow.

The index *will* match if the argument is of type `regconfig`, and so
we try to make sure this happens. We introduce a new scalar type,
`fts::language`, that is compiled to `regconfig`.

The binary serialization for `regconfig` is as an int32, so we
introduce machinery to use the text serialization for regconfig params
instead. (Thanks to @elprans for figuring this trick out.)

We then automatically "promote" `str` params that are casted (possibly
implicitly) to `fts::language` to be `fts::language` params, which lets
using a constant literal param to `language` work right.

The bulk of the code here ends up being code to handle introducing our
first type that we want to use text serialization for in the binary
protocol.

repo.description: A graph-relational database with declarative schema, built-in migration system, and a next-generation query language

issue.title: [DRAFT] An fts::test that hits indexes
issue.body:
Implement an inlined version of fts::test that succefully hits
indexes. (I tested using imdbench extended with some fts::textsearch
indexes, and added some tests to the explain tests)

Per some discussions with @vpetrovykh, I introduced an fts::make_doc
function that is a variadic optional function that produces a string
that can be reasonable passed to an fts::textsearch index and that
works well will fts::test. (fts::test does the same operations.)

make_doc essentially does `array_to_string("docs", ' ')`, but inlined.

The most fiddly bit about all of this, though, in handling the
language argument to postgres's `to_tsvector`, and how it interacts
with our constant extraction preprocessing. Because we extract string
literals during preprocessing, the `language` argument to `fts::test`
and similar will typically be a parameter.

The language argument is of type `regconfig` (which is an int id);
there is a cast from `text` to `regconfig`, but if the argument to
language is a text query parameter cast to `regconfig`, the index will
not match and the query will be slow.

The index *will* match if the argument is of type `regconfig`, and so
we try to make sure this happens. We introduce a new scalar type,
`fts::language`, that is compiled to `regconfig`.

The binary serialization for `regconfig` is as an int32, so we
introduce machinery to use the text serialization for regconfig params
instead. (Thanks to @elprans for figuring this trick out.)

We then automatically "promote" `str` params that are casted (possibly
implicitly) to `fts::language` to be `fts::language` params, which lets
using a constant literal param to `language` work right.

The bulk of the code here ends up being code to handle introducing our
first type that we want to use text serialization for in the binary
protocol.

comment.body:
Going to close this because we went a different direction with FTS.

It's possible that in the future we will end up with a type that needs text serialization, in which case we can recover the whole `needs_text_serialization` machinery from this PR.

Ideally we won't have to, though.
